1.description: Audit remote access tools on your network to identify currently used and/or authorized software.

2.command: Review logs for remote access software
2.description: Review logs for execution of remote access software to detect abnormal use of programs running as a portable executable.

3.description: Use security software to detect instances of remote access software being loaded only in memory.

4.description: Require authorized remote access solutions to be used only from within your network over approved remote access solutions, such as VPNs or VDIs.

5.description: Block both inbound and outbound connections on common remote access software ports and protocols at the network perimeter.

6.description: Implement application controls to manage and control execution of software, including allowlisting remote access programs.

7.description: Strictly limit the use of RDP and other remote desktop services. If RDP is necessary, rigorously apply best practices.

8.description: Audit the network for systems using RDP.

10.description: Enforce account lockouts after a specified number of attempts.

13.description: Disable command-line and scripting activities and permissions.

14.description: Review domain controllers, servers, workstations, and active directories for new and/or unrecognized accounts.

15.command: Audit user accounts with administrative privileges
15.description: Audit user accounts with administrative privileges and configure access controls according to the principle of least privilege (PoLP).

16.command: Place domain admin accounts in protected users’ group
16.description: Place domain admin accounts in the protected users’ group to prevent caching of password hashes locally.

17.description: Refrain from storing plaintext credentials in scripts.

18.description: Implement time-based access for accounts set at the admin level and higher.

19.description: Implement a recovery plan to maintain and retain multiple copies of sensitive or proprietary data and servers in a physically separate, segmented, and secure location.

20.description: Maintain offline backups of data and regularly maintain backup and restoration (daily or weekly at minimum).

21.command: Require password compliance with NIST standards
21.description: Require all accounts with password logins to comply with NIST's standards for developing and managing password policies.

22.description: Use longer passwords consisting of at least eight characters and no more than 64 characters in length.

23.description: Store passwords in hashed format using industry-recognized password managers.

24.description: Add password user “salts” to shared login credentials.

26.description: Implement multiple failed login attempt account lockouts.

28.description: Refrain from requiring password changes more frequently than once per year.

29.command: Require administrator credentials for software installation
29.description: Require administrator credentials to install software.

30.description: Require phishing-resistant multifactor authentication (MFA) for all services to the extent possible.

31.description: Keep all operating systems, software, and firmware up to date. Prioritize patching known exploited vulnerabilities in internet-facing systems.

32.description: Segment networks to prevent the spread of ransomware.

33.command: Identify, detect, and investigate abnormal activity
33.description: Identify, detect, and investigate abnormal activity and potential traversal of the indicated ransomware with a networking monitoring tool.

34.description: Install, regularly update, and enable real time detection for antivirus software on all hosts.

36.description: Consider adding an email banner to emails received from outside your organization.

38.command: Ensure backup data is encrypted and immutable
38.description: Ensure all backup data is encrypted, immutable, and covers the entire organization’s data infrastructure.
